qas.question: According to Hegel, what sort of idealist was Fichte?
Who did Hegel see as a subjective idealist?
What sort of idealist did Hegel define himself as?
How did Hegel believe historical reality to be knowable to a philosopher?
Which two philosophers held to subjective idealism?

plausible_answers.text: the finite and a dialectical philosophy of history

qas.question: What prevents a philosopher from knowing reality?
How did Berkeley label his own idealism?

context: <a2_0>Absolute<a2_0/> idealism is G. W. F. Hegel's account of how existence is comprehensible <b6_0>as an all-inclusive whole<b6_0/>. Hegel called his philosophy "absolute" idealism in contrast to the "<b8_0>subjective<b8_0/> idealism" of <a1_0>Berkeley<a1_0/> and the "<a0_0>transcendental<a0_0/> idealism" of <b4_0>Kant and Fichte<b4_0/>, which were not based on a critique of <b5_0>the finite and a dialectical philosophy of history<b5_0/> as Hegel's idealism was. The <a3_0>exercise of <b7_0>reason and intellect<b7_0/><a3_0/> enables the philosopher to know ultimate historical reality, the phenomenological constitution of self-determination, the dialectical development of self-awareness and personality in the realm of History.
